intro: Acaena polycarpa var. brevifilamentosa, commonly known as the short-filament bramble, is a low-growing shrub native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its dense, thorny stems and small, persistent leaves. The plant produces yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in inflorescences, followed by distinctive burrs containing seeds. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest undergrowth. The species is notable for its ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for native wildlife.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena polycarpa var. brevifilamentosa is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the North Island, particularly in the central and northern regions. This variety thrives in coastal and lowland environments, often in sandy or gravelly soils. It is commonly associated with disturbed habitats such as roadsides and dunes. The plant is part of the bramble family and is known for its distinctive yellow flowers and prickly fruits.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena polycarpa var. brevifilamentosa was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora introduced during the colonial period. This plant is commonly found in disturbed soils and along roadsides in the North Island. It has become naturalized in certain areas, though it is not considered a major invasive species. Its distribution is limited to specific regions where it thrives in sunny, open habitats.
